docs.title: CANI
docs.text: cani is a hardware inventory tool. It provides its own portable inventory format, while retaining compatiblity with external inventory providers. This makes it possible to use cani as either a main inventory source or to migrate from one inventory format to another.

docs.title: cani
docs.text: From subfloor to top-of-rack, manage your HPC cluster's inventory!

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
From subfloor to top-of-rack, manage your HPC cluster's inventory!

cani [flags]

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
--config string   Path to the configuration file
  -D, --debug           additional debug output
  -h, --help            help for cani
  -S, --simulation      Use simulation mode for hsm-simulation-environment

docs.title: SEE ALSO
docs.text:
• cani alpha - Run commands that are considered unstable.
  • cani completion - Generate the autocompletion script for the specified shell
  • cani makedocs - Generate markdown docs to ./docs/

docs.title: SEE ALSO
docs.text:
• cani - From subfloor to top-of-rack, manage your HPC cluster's inventory!
  • cani alpha add - Add assets to the inventory.
  • cani alpha list - List assets in the inventory.
  • cani alpha remove - Remove assets from the inventory.
  • cani alpha session - Interact with a session.
  • cani alpha update - Update assets to the inventory.
  • cani alpha validate - Validate assets in the inventory.
  • cani alpha version - Show the version of this utility.

docs.title: cani alpha add
docs.text: Add assets to the inventory.

docs.title: cani alpha session start
docs.text: Start a session.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
Start a session.

cani alpha session start [flags]

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
--csm-insecure-https   CSM Provider: Allow insecure connections when using HTTPS to CSM services
      --csm-sim-urls         CSM Provider: Use simulation environment URLs
      --csm-url-hsm string   CSM Provider: Base URL for the Hardware State Manager (HSM) (default "https://api-gw-service-nmn.local/apis/smd/hsm/v2")
      --csm-url-sls string   CSM Provider: Base URL for the System Layout Service (SLS) (default "https://api-gw-service-nmn.local/apis/sls/v1")
  -h, --help                 help for start

docs.title: cani completion
docs.text: Generate the autocompletion script for the specified shell

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: Generate the autocompletion script for cani for the specified shell. See each sub-command's help for details on how to use the generated script.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: -h, --help   help for completion

docs.title: Options inherited from parent commands
docs.text:
--config string   Path to the configuration file
  -D, --debug           additional debug output
  -S, --simulation      Use simulation mode for hsm-simulation-environment

docs.title: SEE ALSO
docs.text:
• cani - From subfloor to top-of-rack, manage your HPC cluster's inventory!
  • cani completion bash - Generate the autocompletion script for bash
  • cani completion fish - Generate the autocompletion script for fish
  • cani completion powershell - Generate the autocompletion script for powershell
  • cani completion zsh - Generate the autocompletion script for zsh

docs.title: cani completion bash
docs.text: Generate the autocompletion script for bash

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
Generate the autocompletion script for the bash shell.

This script depends on the 'bash-completion' package. If it is not installed already, you can install it via your OS's package manager.

To load completions in your current shell session:

source <(cani completion bash)

To load completions for every new session, execute once:

docs.title: Linux:
docs.text: cani completion bash > /etc/bash_completion.d/cani

docs.title: macOS:
docs.text:
cani completion bash > $(brew --prefix)/etc/bash_completion.d/cani

You will need to start a new shell for this setup to take effect.

cani completion bash

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
-h, --help              help for bash
      --no-descriptions   disable completion descriptions

docs.title: Options inherited from parent commands
docs.text:
--config string   Path to the configuration file
  -D, --debug           additional debug output
  -S, --simulation      Use simulation mode for hsm-simulation-environment

docs.title: SEE ALSO
docs.text: • cani completion - Generate the autocompletion script for the specified shell

docs.title: cani completion fish
docs.text: Generate the autocompletion script for fish

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
Generate the autocompletion script for the fish shell.

To load completions in your current shell session:

cani completion fish | source

To load completions for every new session, execute once:

cani completion fish > ~/.config/fish/completions/cani.fish

You will need to start a new shell for this setup to take effect.

cani completion fish [flags]

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
-h, --help              help for fish
      --no-descriptions   disable completion descriptions

docs.title: Options inherited from parent commands
docs.text:
--config string   Path to the configuration file
  -D, --debug           additional debug output
  -S, --simulation      Use simulation mode for hsm-simulation-environment

docs.title: SEE ALSO
docs.text: • cani completion - Generate the autocompletion script for the specified shell

docs.title: cani completion powershell
docs.text: Generate the autocompletion script for powershell

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
Generate the autocompletion script for powershell.

To load completions in your current shell session:

cani completion powershell | Out-String | Invoke-Expression

To load completions for every new session, add the output of the above command to your powershell profile.

cani completion powershell [flags]

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
-h, --help              help for powershell
      --no-descriptions   disable completion descriptions

docs.title: Options inherited from parent commands
docs.text:
--config string   Path to the configuration file
  -D, --debug           additional debug output
  -S, --simulation      Use simulation mode for hsm-simulation-environment

docs.title: SEE ALSO
docs.text: • cani completion - Generate the autocompletion script for the specified shell

docs.title: cani completion zsh
docs.text: Generate the autocompletion script for zsh

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
Generate the autocompletion script for the zsh shell.

If shell completion is not already enabled in your environment you will need to enable it. You can execute the following once:

echo "autoload -U compinit; compinit" >> ~/.zshrc

To load completions in your current shell session:

source <(cani completion zsh)

To load completions for every new session, execute once:

docs.title: Linux:
docs.text: cani completion zsh > "${fpath[1]}/_cani"

docs.title: macOS:
docs.text:
cani completion zsh > $(brew --prefix)/share/zsh/site-functions/_cani

You will need to start a new shell for this setup to take effect.

cani completion zsh [flags]

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
-h, --help              help for zsh
      --no-descriptions   disable completion descriptions

docs.title: Options inherited from parent commands
docs.text:
--config string   Path to the configuration file
  -D, --debug           additional debug output
  -S, --simulation      Use simulation mode for hsm-simulation-environment

docs.title: Releasing
docs.text: Releases are created automatically when a stable git tag is created.

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Traditional unit tests for cani are in the *_test.go files. Run go test ./... to run those tests.

Shellspec tests are used for integration-style tests, which test the usability of the CLI interface. Run make shellspec to run those tests.

docs.title: Classification
docs.text:
The items below denote how stable, pre-release, and unstable versions are classified through version strings.

  • (stable) final release: A git-tag following the X.Y.Z semver format is considered a final release version.
# Format:
# {tag}
# X.Y.Z
# X - Major
# Y - Minor
# Z - Micro (a.k.a. patch)
0.1.2
  • (unstable) pre-release: A git-tag with an a(lpha), b(eta), or r(elease) c(andidate) annotation and an identification number N denotes a pre-release/preview.

For canu, these are sometimes created before an official release (e.g. 1.7.0a1 might exist before 1.7.0 is released). Additionally the beta and release candidate tags may be skipped. Whether an alpha, beta, or release candidate pre-release is taken is entirely up to the canu release management team.

# Format:
# {tag}[{a|b|rc}N]
0.1.2a1
0.1.2b1
0.1.2rc1

  • (unstable) development: Development builds auto-increment the micro version (the Z in X.Y.Z) or pre-release version (the N in X.Y.Z{[a|b|rc]N}), and then append a suffix based on whether the working directory was clean, dirty, or mixed.

    • clean: When the version shows an appended devN+{scm_letter}{revision_short_hash}, that means there have been commits made since the previous git-tag.
# Format:
# {next_version}.dev{distance}+{scm_letter}{revision_short_hash}

# If the previous git-tag was 0.1.2:
           0.1.3.dev4+g818da8a

# If the previous get-tag was a pre-release of 0.1.3a1:
         0.1.3a2.dev4+g818da8a

* ***dirty*** When the version shows an appended `.d{YYYYMMDD}` datestamp, that means there were modified/uncommitted changes in the working directory when the application was built.

# Format:
# {next_version}.d(datestamp}

# If the previous git-tag was 0.1.2:
           0.1.3.d20230123

# If the previous get-tag was a pre-release of 0.1.3a1:
         0.1.2a2.d20230123

* ***mixed*** When the version shows a development tag with an appended datestamp, this means commits have been made but there were uncommitted changes present in the working directory when the application was built.

# Format:
# {next_Version}.dev{distance}+{scm_letter}{revision_short_hash}.d{datestamp}

# If the previous git-tag was 0.1.2:
           0.1.3.dev3+g3071655.d20230123

# If the previous get-tag was a pre-release of 0.1.3a1:
         0.1.3a2.dev3+g3071655.d20230123

docs.title: Adding Hardware
docs.text: Systems change over time and adding hardware is often needed to expand the available resources. Equally as common is adding hardware to replace a faulty unit. Once a session has started, adding different types of hardware is possible.

docs.title: Add Hardware
docs.text:
One common use-case is adding a new cabinet to the system.

# example: adding a supported cabinet
# list available types
cani alpha add cabinet --list-supported-types
# add a ex2000 cabinet
cani alpha add cabinet hpe-ex2000

docs.title: List Hardware
docs.text:
The recent addition can be viewed with a list subcommand.

# example: show all cabinets
cani alpha list cabinet

docs.title: Starting A Session
docs.text: All cani operations fall under the purview of a session in which hardware can be added, removed, or updated and is not commited to the external inventory provider until the session is stopped.

docs.title: Start A Session With A Provider
docs.text:
To start a session, you need to choose an inventory provider to work with. At present, the only available option is csm. During session setup, it is also necessary to provide credentials and paths to resources like SLS and HSM.

A common way to interact with a provider is from a local laptop. With the CSM provider, the services are often available over the CMN.

Starting a simple session might look like this, which authorizes a user over the CMN (auth.cmn.example.com and api.cmn.example.com).

Note: This example uses -k (insecure), which is not recommended, but is available for this alpha release

# example: starting a session over the CMN
cani alpha session start csm \
  --csm-keycloak-username username \
  --csm-keycloak-password password \
  --csm-base-auth-url https://auth.cmn.example.com/ \
  --csm-url-sls https://api.cmn.example.com/apis/sls/v1 \
  -k

Just as common, is running cani on an NCN.

Note: since the NCNs have the platform certificates installed, the -k flag is not used

# example: starting a session on an NCN
cani alpha session start csm \
  --csm-keycloak-username username \
  --csm-keycloak-password password \
  --csm-base-auth-url https://api-gw-service-nmn.local/ \
  --csm-url-sls https://api-gw-service-nmn.local/apis/sls/v1

docs.title: Stopping A Session
docs.text: After adding, removing, and/or updating any amount of hardware to the inventory, stopping a sessions runs some validations and prompts for confirmation before commiting the changes.

docs.title: Stop A Session
docs.text:
Stop the session and commit any changes to the external inventory provider.

# example after running some 'cani add', 'cani remove', 'cani update', subcommands
cani alpha session stop # runs validation and if successful, prompts to commit the changes
# example commit changes without prompting
cani alpha session stop --commit

docs.title: Updating Hardware
docs.text: Some providers and some certain types of hardware require additional metadata.

docs.title: Update Hardware
docs.text:
CSM is one such entity. NodeBlades require additional metadata to work properly in SLS and HSM. Running validate will report any such issues and the update subcommand can be used to make the appropriate changes.

# example setting a HMN vlan for a new cabinet
cani alpha add cabinet ex2000
cani alpha validate # shows an error about a missing vlan 
cani alpha update cabinet --vlan-id 4
cani alpha validate # validates ok now

docs.title: Validating
docs.text: In many situations, it is helpful for the inventory provider to validate any changes and for the user to see them.

docs.title: Validate An Inventory
docs.text:
Running the validate subcommand will validate cani's proposed changes with the external inventory provider. If something is missing, the required information is shown for the user to take action on, often through the update subcommand.

# example, validate the existing inventory
cani alpha validate

docs.title: Go Install
docs.text:
1. Install Go.
  2. Clone the cani repo: https://github.com/Cray-HPE/cani.git
  3. Run or build the binary
go run main.go # run the app directly using go
make bin # use the makefile to make the binary with support for the version subcommand
go build -o bin/cani # quickly build without support for the version subcommand

docs.title: RPM Install
docs.text:
Install the latest RPM.

rpm -ivh cani.rpm

docs.title: CSM Inventory Provider
docs.text: cani can read from and push to SLS, CSM's inventory provider. Starting a session with CSM as the provider will handle the translation and reconciliation when performing CRUD operations on the inventory.
